content: what is ndvi value

The NDVI value is a metric that summarizes vegetation health. It is calculated by taking the difference between near infrared reflectance and visible red reflectance, and then dividing that by the sum of near infrared reflectance and visible red reflectance. Before a fire, NDVI values are typically high, and after a fire, NDVI values are typically low. Over time, NDVI values will increase as vegetation recovers. Landsat is particularly useful for mapping abrupt changes in vegetation health, such as forest harvest, forest fire, and conversion of areas to agricultural regions, due to its high resolution of 30 meter pixels. This can be seen in the map of forest loss and gain across the world, where red indicates forest loss, blue indicates forest gain, and green indicates forest extent.
What is the most primitive (i.e. the oldest) form of ocean navigation that we discussed in class?

The most primitive form of ocean navigation discussed in class is pilotage. Pilotage is a form of navigation that is based on visual triangulation to known landmarks and does not require an accurate position. It was used before the 15th century and is still used in coastal navigation today.
How do we define the beginning of space?

We define the beginning of space as the transition between the atmosphere and space, which occurs at about 400 to 500 kilometers above the surface of the Earth. This is known as the Carmen line, an imaginary boundary recognized by the Federation Aeronautique International. At this altitude, air pressure approaches a vacuum, meaning there are very few air molecules and it is considered to be a space. This is the point where the gravitational pull of the Earth is no longer strong enough to keep objects in orbit, and they will begin to fall towards the Earth unless acted upon by other forces.
What is NIR (near infra-red) light frequently used to

Near infrared (NIR) light is frequently used to measure vegetation health, land cover changes, and the composition of an atmosphere. It is also used to map topography and measure the heights of clouds, the top of vegetation canopies, and the distribution of aerosols. NIR light is used in remote sensing to measure the reflectance of wavelengths outside of the visible part of the spectrum, allowing us to gain more information about the characteristics of a surface.

What are the shortest and longest wavelengths sizes of

The shortest wavelength size of electromagnetic radiation is gamma rays, which are typically measured with angstroms, a unit that is about 10 to the power of negative 10 meters. Gamma rays are used in optical telescopes to detect infrared waves, which have longer wavelengths than visible light and can pass through dense regions of gas and dust with lower scattering and absorption. Ultraviolet, visible, and a limited portion of infrared energy together sometimes called short wave radiation from the sun drives our Earth system. The longest wavelength size of electromagnetic radiation is radio waves, which can be several meters long to kilometers long. Radio waves are used to detect the heat generated by the absorption of solar radiation in the atmosphere, which is emitted as long wave infrared radiation, some of which radiates out to space.

what are the dominant factors controlling MIR SWIR reflectance

The dominant factors controlling MIR SWIR reflectance are the amount of water in the leaf, the leaf structure, and the presence of chlorophyll in the palisade parenchyma and spongy mesophyll cells. When leaves are healthy and contain more water, they absorb more energy in the mid-infrared or short wave infrared part of the spectrum, resulting in a lower reflectance. When leaves are drier, there is less water to absorb the energy, resulting in a higher reflectance. The presence of chlorophyll in the palisade parenchyma and spongy mesophyll cells also affects the reflectance, as the chlorophyll absorbs energy in the visible part of the spectrum, while the air pockets in the spongy mesophyll cells allow the near infrared light to bounce around, resulting in higher reflectance.

Given that spatial resolution is 60cm by 60cm, and tennis court lines are usually <20cm, why can we still see the lines on satellite images?

The lines can still be seen on satellite images because of the different spectral responses of the surfaces. The white line reflects a lot of visible light, while the black concrete reflects very little to no visible light. This means that the overall reflectance of the pixel will be relatively high, and the spatial arrangement of the targets allows us to see the two adjacent lines next to each other, rather than them being merged together. The Landsat thematic mapper sensor has seven channels or bands located in the visible, near infrared, mid infrared, and thermal infrared part of the spectrum, with bandwidths ranging from 60 to 270 nanometers. This allows the sensor to detect the differences in reflectance between the white line and the black concrete, and thus the lines can be seen on the satellite images.

For designing a satellite for monitoring regional forest cover change, a moderate spatial resolution of around 20-50 meters would be ideal, as well as a temporal resolution of once or twice a month. The spectral resolution should be high, with multiple narrow bands in the visible red and near infrared portion of the spectrum. This will allow for more accurate detection of different objects and their chemical and structural characteristics. Additionally, the temporal dimension should span a couple of decades in order to monitor forest cover change due to climate change.

What portion of the EM spectrum is used by RADAR

The portion of the EM spectrum used by RADAR is the microwave region, which has a wavelength of 1 millimeter to 1 meter and a frequency of 300 MHz to 300 GHz. This region of the EM spectrum is used to detect energy with wavelengths from 400 to 700 nanometers, the visible light region of the spectrum, as well as other wavelengths outside of the visible light region. Data from multiple wavelengths helps scientists study all kinds of phenomena on Earth from seasonal change to specific habitats. Characteristic patterns within the spectrum allow astronomers to identify an object's chemical composition and to determine such physical properties as temperature and density.
what is the wavelength of RADAR

The wavelength of RADAR is typically in the microwave range, usually between 1 cm and 1 m. This range of wavelengths is used to detect objects by bouncing microwaves off of them and measuring the reflected signal. LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) is a similar technology that uses near infrared light instead of microwaves.
